thread.title_full: World’s tallest building, Burj Khalifa, project director gives Brisbane’s steady rise the thumbs up

author: Sophie Foster
title: World’s tallest building, Burj Khalifa, project director gives Brisbane’s steady rise the thumbs up
text:
THE man behind the tallest building in the world has given Brisbane’s steady rise to world city the thumbs up - predicting it could be “the centre of something big”.
Ahmad Abdelrazaq, who was project director of the Burj Khalifa development as part of his role heading up Samsung’s high-rise division, flew into Brisbane yesterday for an international conference on how cities are responding to urbanism.
“It’s a very nice city and the weather is beautiful today,” he told The Courier-Mail. “My first impression is it’s just one of those cities ready to rise to be the centre of something big.”
He said like most cities Brisbane would have to face the challenge of planning for more densification as greater numbers of people came into the city zone.
“We’re expecting by 2050 that more than 60 to 70 per cent of the population will be living in urban environments.”
Mr Abdelrazaq said it could be a “very good thing”.
“It’s a challenge but a lot of planning can be done, and if it’s done properly it makes the city really work very effectively, more efficiently, with less demand on infrastructure.”
He said Brisbane was “the perfect example” of a city in transition.
”Considering how spread the city is and how beautiful the landscape I think the opportunities are here.”
The half day symposium was hosted by the Australian Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitats with the Brisbane Development Association.
BDA executive director Mark Doonar said it was a timely conference for where Brisbane was at right now.
“We are simply concentrating on what’s the best thing for the city,” he said.
“There’s a risk at the moment for the city that the public debate ends up being tall is bad, dense is bad and these sorts of things, which is not right. If it was bad, people wouldn’t be buying them, people wouldn’t be living in them, and we wouldn’t have wonderful city precincts like Southbank.”
Mr Abdelrazaq said the hope was to move towards “smart cities” which operated efficiently using all the technological advances available.
“Sustainability and environment are very important. Transportation is extremely important, whether people live and walk to their office or whether they drive. Energy is very important,” he said.
“When we can no longer expand horizontally, we have to go vertically, and the question
is infrastructure. Singapore and Hong Kong are very dense but they operate very efficiently using the least amount of energy possible. That’s where we need to go.”
Originally published as Thumbs up for Brisbane’s rise
